content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												This is the game that really started it all off. This game is very much worth the title of the game that started it all of as well. Good on id software on giving us an extra stage. As this game is a beautiful and handcrafted experiance that was rovolutionary for its time. If you didn't know already DOOM was a popular peice of shareware  with a new premise that was scary for its time because of the idea of venturing into hell itself to rid it of every demon in sight the most gory way possible. This ranges from using a shotgun to lay their guts out across the floor of sraight up punching the satanic creatures in to dust.The biggest downfall to the game is the story which is okay, it was the same as hotline miami for me as where it seemed like an excuse to shoot and kill everything is sight, which is totaly okay is you have good game play. This game delivers that exactly.The gameplay ranges from begginer to intermediate puzzles, finding secret rooms, and good 'ol fashoned gore with a range of different weapons. It doesent sound like much on paper and it isn't unless you are playing a higher difficulty. When you play on a higher difficulty you are constantly knee deep in blood and gore the whole time along with taking on a challenge worthy of you're time. There is also a large amount of weapons to work with. The most famous of them is the BFG (look up the acronym for you're selves). Other choices are the shotgun, brass knuckles, handgun, mini gun, and the rocket launcher. The next thing is the puzzles, which usualy consist of finding key cards and opening doors to make your way through the level, some of these can be tedious as it is easy to get lost and not know where you are going.The last feature is the secrets that can be very annoying to find without a guide or else you will be walking around puching ans shooting random walls alot which can also get very annoying.One of the best things about this game is the graphics. Which work around the limitations of the time to create areas that are full of detail and beautiful (technicaly) 2D sprite work of armor and enimies that all mesh together to create a revoulutionary game that almost single handededly formed the FPS genra for years to come. Let me give you some good advice, BUY THIS GAME

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												*IF YOU DON'T FEEL LIKE DOING A LOT OF READING THE VERDICT IS CLEARLY OUTLINED BELOW**NOTICE: I HAVE PLAYED THIS GAME MORE THAN STEAM HAS RECORDED*A classic shooter that not only acted as a fore runner for FPS games to come, but is still a lot of fun to play. Visually, the game isn't super high def PS4/XBox One graphics (obviously), but the cartoony art style coupled with great design on the appearance of the monsters makes this a game that I find pleasing to look at, especially compared to other games which haven't aged well visually. The game runs well for the most part, though I do experience very brief, occasional slow downs, usually when there are a lot of monsters on screen. This brings me to the gameplay: "Doom" is still a very fun game to play (at least in my opinion). Its lack of aiming up and down or need to jump from spot to spot lets the player focus on high speed (I mean seriously fast) strafing and maneuvering to survive the demons that have sought to wreak havoc on our hero. And of course who can forget the lovely sound of heavy metal and shotguns?VerdictDoom is a fast paced FPS that pioneered the genre and is still great fun to this day. It's cartoony graphics have helped the game age suprisingly well visually, while its simple gameplay keeps the action fast and frenetic. Whether you want to play for a few minutes or a few hours, "Doom" will keep you entertained.

!!Important note!! Doom doesn’t work on my windows 10 laptop it crashes at the start, but it is easily fixable, you can download a launcher called zdoom, which is free and you will be able to easily get the game up and running on it. There is a link below to zdoom.   What I liked about Doom •	The game has an awesome soundtrack.•	There are many secrets throughout the levels to be found.  •	The monsters in the game were pretty cool to fight. •	Awesome levels. My favourite chapter in the game is Inferno•	A great arsenal of weapons. The shotgun and the chainsaw were my favourite weapons to use. The weapons have a real kick to them, makes you feel like a badass as you go around killing enemies.   •	I liked how at the end of the levels it showed you a map telling you, where you have been and where you are going to next.•	You can mod the game. Highly recommend you try brutal doom or Project brutality.• I like it how you can see doomguy's face at the bottom of the screen, seeing how he reacts to being shot at or attacked. What I disliked or was disappointed with •	Chapter four isn’t that good. A very difficult chapter, especially at the start.My conclusion Doom was one of the first video games I ever played, I have fond memories of it. It is a brilliant first person shooter and made even better with brutal doom or project brutality. I highly recommend it.  83/100Zdoom http://zdoom.org/Downloadbrutal doom http://www.moddb.com/mods/brutal-doom

												There's not a whole lot to be said about DOOM that hasn't been said beforeIt's a great game. With all the secrets, and enemies to annihilate. Small choice of weapons, but that's no problem.Four episodes with 7 missions each, 8 if you count the boss battle at the end of each episode.To this day DOOM still looks good.It'll run on just about anything with a processor and graphics card.The game doesn't cost a lot. It'd be a good decision to just buy the complete package.There is Satanic imagery for anyone who's a wuss and is worried about that - wouldn't want you to cry if you reach that cyberdemon.As this is a older game it'll be running on DOSBox, I had to change my output type to OpenGL but after that everything was smooth sailing. No framerate issues here.Lighting can be a bit weird in certain places, but it adds to the atmosphere.It's a good FPS give it a try if you haven't played it yet.

												Back in 1993, all we had was MS-DOS and a copy of DOOM. Instead of pressing start on your Xbox Controller, we had to type in terribly long commands. But that long journey was worth it. We got to slaughter demons and destroy Hell itself! Now, we're in an age of Call of Duty and DLC. DOOM has risen to steam as... THE ULTIMATE DOOM! The game works real well and everything just feels like your playing on an old school DOS Computer! To step up the fun, download Brutal Doom. Brutal Doom makes everything better like Fatalities, more gore, and health bonuses for brutally killing Imps and Lost Souls! Another thing that I like about Ultimate Doom is how it includes a fourth episode, Thy Flesh Consumed. It's kinda like a prequel to DOOM II Hell on Earth. If you don't know about this game, you're just a sad shell living under a rock playing Call of Duty Black Ops. Everything about DOOM is just so... AWESOME. If you haven't played this game yet, buy it now on Steam for just $4.99. Overall, The Ultimate DOOM gets a 19/10! Why? BECAUSE IT'S AWESOME!

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												Back in 1993, all we had was MS-DOS and a copy of DOOM. Instead of pressing start on your Xbox Controller, we had to type in terribly long commands. But that long journey was worth it. We got to slaughter demons and destroy Hell itself! Now, we're in an age of Call of Duty and DLC. DOOM has risen to steam as... THE ULTIMATE DOOM! The game works real well and everything just feels like your playing on an old school DOS Computer! To step up the fun, download Brutal Doom. Brutal Doom makes everything better like Fatalities, more gore, and health bonuses for brutally killing Imps and Lost Souls! Another thing that I like about Ultimate Doom is how it includes a fourth episode, Thy Flesh Consumed. It's kinda like a prequel to DOOM II Hell on Earth. If you don't know about this game, you're just a sad shell living under a rock playing Call of Duty Black Ops. Everything about DOOM is just so... AWESOME. If you haven't played this game yet, buy it now on Steam for just $4.99. Overall, The Ultimate DOOM gets a 19/10! Why? BECAUSE IT'S AWESOME!

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												I haven't played this game because it looks too scary but it asks a really important question in the title: What is the ULTIMATE DOOM? I personally think it would be when you go to hell and they give you a really nice girl to talk to and you seem to be getting along very well, but then you accidentally fall over because you are trying to tie up your shoes and touch her leg and she calls the police. But because this is hell this probably happens forever and instead of a long court case and a moderate fine plus 48 hours of community service instead you go to HELL PRISON or something, which is like normal prison except instead of food you get knives and spikes and stuff, and instead of a bed you get like tarantulas or something. Maybe not tarantulas actually, once i went to the zoo and there was a tarantula and it wasn't really that scary because the man let me hold it although  it did crawl up my wrist and i did have to buy the zoo a new one because i trod on it when i went back to my seat. It was definitely his fault for letting me drop the tarantula though since i am not a tarantula expert. Overall i have to guuess that if you like scary games then this one is the scariest and therefore the best so buy it you will not be disappointed unless you prefer less scary games like Snake II on the nokia phone.

Posted: June 20, 2016
												The game, the legend, real mass fps starts here. Solid and tight controls, fast gameplay, reactive monsters, memorable music that gets countless remixes to this day. A blast from the past that still packs a punch and stands up to most fps made to this day. Map design is great, monster selection is ok, weapons are good, atmosphere is great, graphics - a pass considering the ancient legacy this game holds.Play with mods such as brutal doom and expanded engine such as gzdoom.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												This game is the best FPS that was ever created, and will stay as the best FPS that was ever created forevermore. Just like what Megadeth is for the thrash metal, and what Iron Maiden is for the heavy metal, Doom is the ultimate accelerator factor behind the FPS genre. It's the game that opened up the doors for the FPS to grow, and become what it is today (an outlet for the 12 year old casual kids to play their crappy call of duty games and insult people's mothers over voice chat, sadly lmfao). Not only that, but arguably it is the first and foremost game (or even if it's not, it's still the most important one, and I accept no arguments over that) that opened up the doors of modding! You thought that modding community of Bethesda was pretty sick, if you are thinking that, you've seen nothing yet. The scale of modifications and .WADs created for this game is INSANE, and even after 20 years, new content for the old Doom games are still being released religiously by fans, even today! With the same Doom 1 engine that was created 20 years ago, if fans are able to recreate fairly accurate SONIC THE HEDGEHOG games, this tells many things, doesn't it? To me, it means not only it's just an FPS game, but this game can turn into whatever the hell you want it to be, even 20 years later, lol. They made a huge fuss over that triviality called Hatred, and gave it a bunch of free publicity a year ago... Obviously they don't even know the true meaning of BRUTALITY - if you know what I mean ;) - and therefore they lack the slightest imagination to think of anything remotely similar. What foolish mortals. But seriously jokes aside, ignorant people like them who don't even know proper knowledge about the things they want to critise, shouldn't even be allowed to do so. (*coughdidsomeonesaysarkeesiancough*) Because common sense, really. And this is a general rule of thumb in life, if you ask me.To finalize, if this game is able to turn me into a giddy child with it's modifications, even after 20 years later, this tells pretty much all you need to hear I think.FINAL verdict - once again - the greatest FPS of all time.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												The invention of iron sights is the reason modern shooters suck.  Forcing the player to make a clear distinction between attack and defense changes the whole pace, it encourages things like chest high walls and shooting gallery level design.  Imagine an FPS from a time before that.  When you could run fast, and also shoot at the same time.  When enemies were everywhere instead of in the Designated Setpiece Areas.  When even designing levels in 3D was new and exciting, and the best minds in gaming were thinking deeply about level design.  If you haven't played DOOM, you don't know jack ♥♥♥♥in♥♥♥♥♥♥about FPSes.There are demons.  You need to shoot them in the face, now.  Go.

												The game, the legend, real mass fps starts here. Solid and tight controls, fast gameplay, reactive monsters, memorable music that gets countless remixes to this day. Map design is great, monster selection is ok, weapons are good, atmosphere is great, graphics - a pass considering the ancient legacy this game holds.Play with mods such as brutal doom and expanded engine such as gzdoom.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Bought it for H-DoomI regretNOTHINGOTHINGOn a serious note:This is the mother of shooters (next to Wolfenstein 3d being...the grandmother then?)Who does not know Doom?Doom pretty much made the fundament of what shooters are today. We cannot deny doom did nothing, they pretty much started with shooters back then, of course they had to test things. Why not demons? Ok, let's use demons and see how people react. And oh boy...what an impact it had, has and will still have. Let's be honest: Am I the only one who thinks E1M1's soundtrack (1. level) is pretty much the best? I am no big fan of metal, but omg, that one just makes me wanna go off an shoot demons! ...wait, that is the actual setting of the game...What can I really say about the gameplay...well...the original controls were the arrow pads while Ctrl (I think) being the shooting button.  you have weak enemies, having a pistol or a shotgun, tankers, dealing mediocre damage but being able to take a lot of damage, and ememies, who are just strong, having the ability to fly and deal a lot of damage or just take a lot of damage and dealing a lot. Every enemy has a specific weakness, each one's different. Ofc, a BFG 9000 (i'll talk about the weapons soon) is definetly effective against everyone, but wasting that ammo for some Imps? Not useful. Ammo management is also important, so dont just foolishly spend your minigunammo. Use the shotgun or rocketlauncher, depending on the situation.So we can say, the game requires you to think (*cough* COD *cough*)The weapon choice is alright. In total, we have 8 weapons. The fists (pretty much your last choice you should use. DO NOT), the chainsaw (TIMBER), the shotgun (in Doom 2 we also have the double barreled shotgun), the pistol (semi-useful against weak enemies), the chaingun (your "rifle" in this game, sharing the pistol ammo), the rocketlauncher (dont need to add anything), the plasmarifle (strong, fast shooting rifle) and the BFG 9000, sharing the plasmarifle ammo (its name really is Big ♥♥♥♥ing Gun 9000). you will know how to use them when playing. BFG of course is the weapon against everything using 60 plasmarifle ammo. while the chaingun is actually useful against everything, it will show its weakness against tanks or high-HP enemies (you will have to use a lot of ammo). Again, the ammomanagement but also the weaponvariety back then! Think of it!The last point I want to talk about are the maps:We have 4 chapters with 9 levels each (if I am not mistaken). each of them isnt just like a narrow path you have to follow, you sometimes have to do some backtracking to collect that one keycard you need for the final door. Or you have to solve a little puzzle to reach the end of the level/the next segment of the game. Enemies are placed in a good way, not bothering you but still surprising you at least a bit. And, many people sadly don't know this anymore: Secrets! For those picky people not living with the fact letting bits o' loot in a level, you can look for secrets! Some are quite easy to solve (walking against a wall, pressing the interaction key, normally space; or shooting against a wall) while others require you to think (eg you have to walk back to a specific point of the map and then running afap to the elevator, leading you to the secret). Something for everybody: not too narrow and challenging!Oh, the game has 5 difficulties. the first and second are not worth to try. go for the third or fourth, depending on how tough you think you are. DO NOT TRY NIGHTMARE. DO. NOT. DO. IT.But if you do, record it and show the world you are one of the best players around. Only a few managed to speedrun nightmare (as far as I know). It's really hard. For more informations what NIGHTMARE covers, look it up.One last tip:Use a "newer" software for Doom. DosBos is ~quite~ alright, but I highly recommend programs like zandronum. It automatically sees similar doom programs (mods) and plays them with but a single doubleclick with the doom engine.If you excuse me, the girls in H-Doom need some of René Descartes(if you get this joke, please comment this)PS:Oh, and dont think I dont know the game. I played this game around a year ago, I'd roughly say I have around at least 100 hours with it

												As-is? Don't waste your money. A pathetic DOSBox release with no useful features etc.Follow this guide (took me literally 5 minutes to set it up)


How to run ports\mods through Steam using ZDL 
A Guide for The Ultimate DOOM
By: Bunnings Wharehouse

			A guide to help people run modern Doom ports through Steam using ZDL, this enables Steam Overlay in the modern ports and keeps track of gaming hours.		


And THEN you have a highly enjoyable DOOM experience. Brutal DOOM works, I also tried some other mods like Pirate DOOM and the ZDL loader is a heaven-sent utility.I'm not going to waste space reviewing the game, it's a classic, it's the♥♥♥♥♥♥ it's my favourite game of all time and blah blah blah nostalgia glasses: activate. The first three episodes are pinnacles of 90s FPS perfection, episode four is a bit bland by comparison, and that's all I'm saying.I just wanted to set the record straight that DOOM can be run like clockwork through Steam thanks to this loader.And for those saying "but why should I have to do this if I paid money for it!", I say "Do whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you want, but if you want a good way of playing DOOM through Steam wiht next to no effort, well, here it is."

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												I've been loving DOOM ever since as a kid, except that I haven't played it until just recently. I gotta say, it hasn't disappointed the slightest bit. In fact it is currently my favorite game. It has all the elements I find enjoyable in a game: simple premise, quiet protagonist, awesome music, rich atmosphere, ultra-violence, great sound effects, sarcasm and of course controversy. It must have been quite a sight seeing the Satanist imagery in the game and how hell is portrayed. That provoked people. I like stuff that provokes people. Anyway, I gotta say even though the game is old, I find the game as exciting to play as when I play Demon's Souls/Dark Souls or Fallout. The game can creep me out and give me a shock. Or make me desperate. I don't mind the simple controls, or the fact that the protagonist can't look up or down. When you play the game, you're not in it for sightseeing, you're in it to turn monsters into meatpulp! Legendary game. I strongly recommend it. Oh, it is nice you have the option of using two kinds of control settings, classic or updated. Both are fun but the classic setting is more challenging. The more challenging it is, the more rewarding it is.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												I bought this on Steam just so I could write a review of it, and maybe push id in the right direction with sales. I have actually played this game for hundreds of hours. I probably play it for at least 10-20 hours per year, for every year of my life.Let me make one thing perfectly clear: nostalgia does not factor into this game's enjoyment. Doom still has a very active community, and new mods come out all the time. Thanks to Carmack's programming, Doom made modding a staple of PC gaming, and it hasn't gone away. Getting older has made me see more of Doom's flaws, but I don't really like it any less.Doom is far from perfect. Unlike modern corridor shooters, which almost completely abandon the principles of level design, Doom is made or broken by its level design. There are a few different level designers that worked on Doom, and once you've played enough you can tell each of them just by playing their levels, even if you don't know their names. This means that level design is inconsistent, and therefore you're going to really like some levels and hate others. Most people who played Doom as a kid forgave the bad levels because, well, they were kids. If you're new to Doom, it's best to start at the beginning and play Episode 1 of Doom 1. This is widely regarded as one of the best, if not the best, set of levels for Doom, designed by John Romero. They're coherent, look nice (relatively speaking) and have well-placed secrets. Oddly enough, Doom 64 has one of the best sets of levels and plays like any of the other classic Doom games; google "Doom 64 Absolution" and you can easily find a total conversion mod that basically allows you to play Doom 64 on your computer once you have Doom. Thanks, Midway!Virtually every level can be summed up by "find keys, throw switches, open doors." This sounds bad, but again, it can either be tedious or enjoyable depending on the level's design. I must stress that the player should use their automap (tab key) here. Doom's levels are not afraid of having many twisting paths, and it's quite easy to get lost without it. Helpfully, switches are usually recessed into the wall slightly, which clearly marks them on the automap. If levels truly become tedious, don't be afraid to skip them by typing "IDCLEVXX", where "XX" is a two-digit number following the convention of episode number, then level number. i.e. IDCLEV14 changes to episode 1, level 4. Each episode has 9 levels. I won't lie to you, there are a few quite truly bad levels in Doom, but fortunately id left this cheat code in. Be careful, it starts the level as if you'd started a new game, which means you lose all your weapons except the pistol, and start with 100 health and 0 armor. However, all Doom levels are designed with pistol start in mind, so you should be able to manage with enough skill. Doom should be enjoyed on a level-by-level basis; remember, there is almost nothing in the narrative that ties these levels together. If you really hate a level, you should get used to the idea of just skipping it.The guns... well, everyone knows how the guns work, since they were the basis for almost every shooter arsenal until Unreal came out, notable exception being Rise of the Triad. They're quite well-balanced, actually, with the exception of the pistol, which becomes useless once you get the chaingun. The shotgun and chaingun are good at long range. The super shotgun is probably the best all-around weapon in the game, although it doesn't appear until Doom 2. The rocket launcher and plasma rifle are high-power weapons meant to break out against threatening hordes of monsters, and the BFG is there when nothing else substitutes.  Every one of them has a place in your arsenal, although depending on the levels you're playing, you may be using one a lot more than the other due to ammo distribution. Doom is famously narrative-light. Romero makes a good effort to portray "realistic" military base locations, but the game's somewhat ridiculously deep story penned by Tom Hall was thrown out in short order - trust me, if you'd have read it, you would agree that it is quite over-the-top for a fledgling shooter made in 1993. The inconsistency between levels means that the ultimate choice to abandon any hope of telling a story beyond the intermission text screens was probably for the best. There are a few key events that happen in the plot, but they mostly happen at the end of or between episodes.Overall, I highly recommend Doom for anyone who enjoys shooters but hasn't played Doom before. I also recommend Doom for anyone who is new to shooters, since it was also designed for that audience. If nothing else, it will give them an appreciation for where the genre has come from. This game still holds up very well today, especially with the active modding community. HOWEVER: If you do buy this game, do NOT run it as-is from Steam's library. To run the game on modern systems, it comes packaged with DOSBox, which simulates the MS-DOS environment. The emulation can slow down your computer considerably and ironically make running the game more difficult. You should instead download and install one of the many "source ports," which are redesigns of the actual game engine to make it compatible with modern computers. ZDoom is a good and popular choice. Some "purists" swear by Chocolate Doom, which faithfully recreates the game, merely updating it to allow it to run on modern hardware without such niceties as OpenGL or mouselook.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												My UnAPologeticly Bias Review of DOOM 1993 "The Year Gaming Began"It was 1993, What a great year, Bill Clinton in the Whitehouse, The Simpsons & The X-Files on Your TV........And more importantly DOOM on your PCIn 1993 Id Software, The 5 or so Developers of DOOM said FU****CK All this 2D kiddie Garbage and made Game for "Real Gamers" a Game SO EPIC and so Controversial that it has Become the be all and end all In gaming, This Game was so good it inspired many Clones,Mass Shootings, Outrage and Set in stone a template for all future "FIRST PERSON" Games ever to be released , It Stated with with one Simple One simple Philosophy,One Powerful Formula...."Hoards of Evil Enemies bent on World Domination and An Arsenal of Bad A**ss Weapons to Dispatch them With"Here's my review of One of the GREATEST and BEST FIRST PERSON SHOOTER EVER MADETHE AWSOME+The Setting..Its the far Future , Man has invented Teleportation Device and Whoops Dimension Rip , Hoards of DEMONS from hell are pouring out Massacring The Entire Phobos Moon Research Base staff, You are the Lonely Space Marine and you have one Job...WIPE THEM OUT. (play Doom 3 To get the full story) + Weapons are all kids of Awesome, Rip through the DEMON HOARDS with an Array of Awesome Reaslsitc Weapons such as the Shotgun, Pistol and Demon shredding CHAIN GUN and some Sci Fi Weapons like the Plasma rifle and BFG. For some reason there a Chainsaw too, it's not great but Has great potential for Gory kills for the more violent minded player.+The Music is Awsome , It's Like a Rock Concert, and if any one tells your differently tell them to F off. The music is perfect for Chain gunning your way through Hells finest+Modern Controls ,the game uses WASD and mouse to Shoot instead of the weird system they had in 1993.+CARRY 10 GUNS at once none of this 3 gun limit Bullsh*it+The One Retro game u can't be accused of being a hipster for Playing. It's too Awsome for that +U NEE ETO PLAY IT+It's History The bad...more like nit picks - Graphics,  I'm not gonna bash on it too much , there a little dull , it's a mixed bag of grey room, red room, at least it wasent 2D- Finding Key cards can be annoying in Later Levels- you can't Aim up and down, has an Auto Aim of sorts , some Whimps (Pretentious know it all Gamers, your know who u are) out there might complain about thatWait a Minuet your still, reading this long boring review ...what the F are u Doing....get up off your butt, get down to the bank and drop some dollar into that steam account of yours (if u haven't already) and buy DOOM ...RIGHT NOW AND PLAY ITS AWSOME GOODNESSNOW GO and Buy and Enjoy this Gaming piece of History> Oh And Remember Kids"Without Doom , your crappy arsed kiddie Call of Duty Garbage wouldn't exist"DOOM gets the rare Daire OReilly "Best Game Ever" Seal of ApprovalMy Score 666/10UPDATE: Steam Awards December 2016: I nominated this game for the "Test of Time" award because i trully think that this game will live on forever. this game derves it

Unlike modern corridor shooters, which almost completely abandon the principles of level design, Doom is made or broken by its level design. There are a few different level designers that worked on Doom, and once you've played enough you can tell each of them just by playing their levels, even if you don't know their names. This means that level design is inconsistent, and therefore you're going to really like some levels and hate others. Most people who played Doom as a kid forgave the bad levels because, well, they were kids. If you're new to Doom, it's best to start at the beginning and play Episode 1 of Doom 1. This is widely regarded as one of the best, if not the best, set of levels for Doom, designed by John Romero. They're coherent, look nice (relatively speaking) and have well-placed secrets. Oddly enough, Doom 64 has one of the best sets of levels and plays like any of the other classic Doom games; google "Doom 64 Absolution" and you can easily find a total conversion mod that basically allows you to play Doom 64 on your computer once you have Doom. Thanks, Midway!Virtually every level can be summed up by "find keys, throw switches, open doors." This sounds bad, but again, it can either be tedious or enjoyable depending on the level's design. I must stress that the player should use their automap (tab key) here. Doom's levels are not afraid of having many twisting paths, and it's quite easy to get lost without it. Helpfully, switches are usually recessed into the wall slightly, which clearly marks them on the automap. If levels truly become tedious, don't be afraid to skip them by typing "IDCLEVXX", where "XX" is a two-digit number following the convention of episode number, then level number. i.e. IDCLEV14 changes to episode 1, level 4. Each episode has 9 levels. I won't lie to you, there are a few quite truly bad levels in Doom, but fortunately id left this cheat code in. Be careful, it starts the level as if you'd started a new game, which means you lose all your weapons except the pistol, and start with 100 health and 0 armor. However, all Doom levels are designed with pistol start in mind, so you should be able to manage with enough skill. Doom should be enjoyed on a level-by-level basis; remember, there is almost nothing in the narrative that ties these levels together. If you really hate a level, you should get used to the idea of just skipping it.The guns... well, everyone knows how the guns work, since they were the basis for almost every shooter arsenal until Unreal came out, notable exception being Rise of the Triad. They're quite well-balanced, actually, with the exception of the pistol, which becomes useless once you get the chaingun. The shotgun and chaingun are good at long range. The super shotgun is probably the best all-around weapon in the game, although it doesn't appear until Doom 2. The rocket launcher and plasma rifle are high-power weapons meant to break out against threatening hordes of monsters, and the BFG is there when nothing else substitutes.  Every one of them has a place in your arsenal, although depending on the levels you're playing, you may be using one a lot more than the other due to ammo distribution. Doom is famously narrative-light. Romero makes a good effort to portray "realistic" military base locations, but the game's somewhat ridiculously deep story penned by Tom Hall was thrown out in short order - trust me, if you'd have read it, you would agree that it is quite over-the-top for a fledgling shooter made in 1993. The inconsistency between levels means that the ultimate choice to abandon any hope of telling a story beyond the intermission text screens was probably for the best. There are a few key events that happen in the plot, but they mostly happen at the end of or between episodes.Overall, I highly recommend Doom for anyone who enjoys shooters but hasn't played Doom before. I also recommend Doom for anyone who is new to shooters, since it was also designed for that audience. If nothing else, it will give them an appreciation for where the genre has come from. This game still holds up very well today, especially with the active modding community. HOWEVER: If you do buy this game, do NOT run it as-is from Steam's library. To run the game on modern systems, it comes packaged with DOSBox, which simulates the MS-DOS environment. The emulation can slow down your computer considerably and ironically make running the game more difficult. You should instead download and install one of the many "source ports," which are redesigns of the actual game engine to make it compatible with modern computers. ZDoom is a good and popular choice. Some "purists" swear by Chocolate Doom, which faithfully recreates the game, merely updating it to allow it to run on modern hardware without such niceties as OpenGL or mouselook.

												WINDOWS 8 OR ABOVE USERS NEED CHOCOLATE DOOM OR ZDOOM TO RUN THIS! (DON'T WORRY ZDOOM AND CHOCOLATE DOOM ARE FREE)Graphics 4/5Level design 4/5 Music 5/5Demons 666/5A timeless classic that has something for everyone. Simple gameplay for people new to games, Fast paced action shooting for FPS fans and keycard collecting for weirdo's  who like to collect keycards. Now where's the red keycard?The game is about shooting demons and going to hell, thats all. Every in the weapon is useful (exept the pistol and fist if you don't have the beserker powerup). The weapons you will be using the most are the shotgun, minigun and rocket launcher. Later on in the game you will be using the plasma gun and BFG. The enemys in doom are fun to fight against and you need to find to perfect weapon to use against them. First you got zombies/possessed soldiers with guns, Imps that throw fireballs, flying demon strawberries and a GIANT goat person with a missile launcher for an arm. The music is the best part. Though it is stolen from other artists like metallica, Pantera, Slayer and Alice in chains. But it does not stop it from being good, Infact it makes it sound cooler. If your playing doom in a sourceport like ZDOOM it uses the soundfont on your computer which makes it 10 times better.just get it or I WILL RIP AND TEAR HUGE GUTS!!! YOU HAVE HUGE GUTS NOT GETTING THIS!!! RIP AND TEEEEEAAAAAAAAARRRRRRR!!!!!!!!!WINDOWS 8 OR ABOVE USERS NEED CHOCOLATE DOOM OR ZDOOM TO RUN THIS!

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Oddly enough, I played DOOM II before DOOM in 95, so this was really my second installment in the series, about two years later. Back in 1995 things were simpler — I only had DOOM II, and Hover! so I could just play the obvious choice; come 1996 and (Final) DOOM, and choices were not that easy anymore: there also were Grand Prix 2 and FIFA 97 to be taken care of. Well, even though the choice wasn't easy, it always boiled down to my favourite meat-grinding, first-person gore party. I believe — and this is probably just my heart talking — DOOM II was far better than the original, but even then I knew perfectly that this would be a milestone, this would matter, this would've made history.It's not too late to claim your part in it.

Posted: February 11, 2015
												An MS-DOS Classic from my Childhood. Now with "Episode 4: Thy Flesh Consumed." An extra Episode that's not even in the Original DOOM. My Review on DOOM needs no Introduction.The Storyline is simple, you're a Space Marine that's transfered to Mars as Security for the Union Aerospace Corporation or UAC While they conduct Teleportation Experments on Mars' 2 Moons; Phobos and Deimos. But when a Teleportation Experment goes astary due to a terrible accident, Phobos Base sends out a distress signal while Deimos Base drops dead & disappears completely. Responding to a frantic distress call from the overrun scientists, the Martian marine unit is quickly sent by ship from Mars to Phobos to investigate, only to find the Phobos Completely overrun by devilspawns from the Gates of Hell & there's one option left: LOCK & LOAD!

content:
Posted: April 19, 2016
												Consider this a review of all classic Doom games.I love Doom. I didn't grow up playing games lime these, heck, I didn't grow up playing games at all.Doom is without a doubt, the best FPS ever made.BUTDon't play this version. Obviously buy it, but don't play this version.Buy the steam versions, but download a sourceport like Zdoom or Zandronium to play them instead. DOS-box is complete garbage, this is a terrible port. The controls are very wonky, and the games look very pixely on this version. Sourceports are the best way to play vanilla Doom, they add better texturing, and higher resolutions for those of us with 16:9 monitors.And also they add a whole slew of options for modding, one of the most popular being Brutal Doom.And last but not least, don't buy the new Doom, it looks like crap, like Halo and a tacked on Multiplayer with terrible Matchmaking.Good day.

number of helpful: 58 of 123 people (47%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
The Ultimate DooM		* 10/10The Ultimate DooM on Steam		* 0/10I believe there's not much to say about DooM. Not the first FPS, but I could say it's "The First Bad@$$ FPS Ever. PERIOD". Why the 2 rates? Let's say the 10/10 rate is related to the Game itself (or every Pros I've though of and listed) while the 0/10 is related to the Game As a Steam Release (Everything is listed in the Cons Section). Consider that I grew up with doom, I was 6 years old when the shareware was being widespread all over the world, and still nowadays I own The original DooM, DooM II and The Ultimate Collection DooM 95 (With Ultimate DooM, DooM II And Final DooM). Despite all this I regret to NOT Recommend this RELEASE (Not THE GAME, mind you). On a Side note: all the DooM chapters have been released on Steam like this, so I'm not recommending Any other chapter, specifically DooM II, Final DooM nor even the Master levels for DooM II. My same Review will be posted in all those releases because of the same flaws.+++PROs+++The Following Points are the reason I MUST recommend this Game FPS. The genre was defined by THIS game (Yes, yes, there was Wolfenstein before, but the mainstream came with DooM overwhelming popularity). I still feel Adrenaline while sporting around an arsenal of weapons through Maps totally full of monsters and a gameplay that can be summarized as "shoot (or run through) everything that moves and get to the exit". Sounds lame but everything started from here, and simpler things are not boring here. They're Fun. MUSIC. It's a widely known story and it's true. Most of the bad@$$ music you hear in game are nothing but ripoffs from famous Metal or Hard Rock famous songs. How could a game be more Bad@$$ than this? MODS. One of the most Modded game ever. There are even lots of Ports, because DooM originally is a DOS game so it always had few issues with windows' environment (mainly audio related, who remembers autoexec.bat, dos=high umb and other damn DOS lines like them? XD). Lots of famous mods, that can revolutionize the gameplay (like Brutal Doom), or even new maps (See Alien DooM), or totally messed up demented projects (like the Italian And somehow Satyrical/blatantly blasphemous Grezzo 2... I am told it's greatly appreciated around the world... even though most characters are italian or from italian Television, and everything is written/spoken in italian... so... O.o). There are even lots of guides, both in steam and in other sites, with solutions to all of the CONs I've listed.---CONs---The following points are the reason I will NEVER recommend this release on Steam. STEAM OVERLAY. This release runs directly with dosbox, so obviously the overlay won't work. THE PORT. Actually this release has no ports... It's the usual game that runs on DosBox... Which is not the best solution because it's just an emulation of a DOS Environment which means that you can easily experience some minor LAGs, both on video and audio. Not to mention the inferior Midi quality. On top of that it has 2 options, the classic input and the DEFAULT "Modern input" with WASD Movement AND Mouse MOVEMENT...Not Mouselook, MOVEMENT. So obviously you can't use the mouse because it goes in conflict with the WASD keys... And you can't use the arrows because ONLY Left and Right are Binded... WHAT THE F**K?!?!?!?!? WHO THE HELL IS THE INCOMPETENT THAT WORKED ON THIS $H17 AND APPROVED IT?!?!?!?!? AND THIS C**P IS THE DEFAULT SETTING!!!! I know there are solutions inside steam's community discussions and guides, but I don't care, releasing a product of the importance as DooM in this state is SIMPLY RIDICULOUS. And you want to know something? Do you remember the Excellent DooM 95 Port where you have a simple window with tidy options and settings? You even have settings to add Mods. Do you know who worked on that project in his Microsoft's days? GABE NEWELL. And here on Steam I have to find this Garbage on DosBox... I could have Downloaded from google in 2 minutes both the WADs AND a DECENT Port IF (i repeat) IF MY ORIGINAL COPIES  Of DooM, DooM II And "Ultimate Doom, DooM II And Final With DooM 95" (Yes I DO OWN ALL OF THEM) were somehow misteriously Burnt out... Steam doesn't consider profitable to ask microsoft a deal to use the best BASIC port for DooM? Fine, Use another one, or make something decent yourself, it's really ridiculous to get such a great game released in such a bad and approximate way... And maybe I'm mistaken, Steam is just a digital distribution platform and the quality of the product released relies on the Developer. It doesn't change anything. The fact that Whoever worked on this release setted the game to play by default with a SELF-CONTRADICTORY INPUT SYSTEM is still RIDICUOUS ... And a reason BIG ENOUGH to AVOID this release LIKE A DISEASE... (Ho-ho-ho, I'm a poet... XD... But seriously, don't waste here your money...)

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												Honestly, it's a bit clunky. Not being able to look up or down is always annoying. Even worse, moving the mouse forward or back instead moves me forwards or backwards, which is really annoying when I'm trying not to fall. I mean, seriously, what FPS does that, having the mouse move the player? It goes against every gaming instinct I've developed from FPSs.As far as I know, there's no way to change the controls, so I'm stuck with this bass ackwards mouse control.Other than that, there's not much to say. I mean, it's the original DOOM, pretty much. An all-time classic. I would say it's aged relatively well. Graphics can get repetitive, what you have to do isn't always straightforward, and some times the game makes you jump through extra hoops just for some cheap hits (if I remember correctly, in E1M4, you have to get the red keycard, which sets off a flag for more enemies to be released, and you have to get through them to get the blue keycard). But overall, it's fun, it's challenging, and it's DOOM.Hell awaits you... Are you ready for it?

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												The game itself being "DOOM" is an excellent fps that defined the genre, but this version is not very good. This DOOM port is  a DOS emulator with the DOOMrom attatched. This means that it is poorly optimized for a modern computer. There is a lack of any controller options, meaning you have to use the origional control scheme which is very tank-like, using the arrow keys to go forward, back, and turining while using the "ctrl" key to fire and holding "alt" to strafe. The mouse support is awful simply acting as the arrow keys. A better DOOM for a modern machine is DOOM 3 bfg edition. This includes all of the DOOM games and all have been updated for a new computer with modern fps controls.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												If you are looking to relive the classic D00M experience on a system newer than Windows 98, this is not the game for you. Unlike the Ultimate Edition that came with pre-ordering Doom3 all those years ago, or the relatively recent BFG Edition, which both modernized and created a compatible experience for current systems, this version of the Ultimate Doom launches through "DOSBox" Emulator. This in of itself would not be a deal breaker... if of course, it worked, and I didn't pay actual money for it!Colour pallete and compatibility issues as well as the game becoming unresponsive seconds into a new game are the name of the game. Unfortunately, as much as I adore this franchise, the pricetag does not justify the *very* brief glimpse of nostalgia you will get from this title; much less buying the bundle pack, as I did. That's $26.00 AUD I'm never going to see again.It truely is painful to have to speak ill of the game that consumed so much of my childhood, it truely, truely is...Rip and Tear away from this.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												The Ultimate in Bad Ports.If you couldn't tell from the official screenshots with warped colors, this features terrible modern hardware support. How bad? No OpenGL/DirectX. Software Rendering Only. Locked 480p 4:3 Resolution. This is only worth buying for the data files, which you should proceed to use in a newer Source Port engine."This is the roots of PC Gaming on Windows people thanks to Gabe Newell who offered to port it." -Just Good PC GamesThe above statement is an obviously paid lie. Calling this a port at all is outright dishonest. This crap got shoved onto steam when Bethesda got the Id catalog, and it's an outdated unpatched dos version running in an emulator. Gabe did nothing, and in no way is this a Windows NT port, but a disgusting cashgrab by Bethesda using a DOS emulator they also didn't develop.Any other avenue for legally acquiring those files is better than this. This is an awful hackjob that no one should support Bethesda with. If you don't believe me, go look at Super Noah's Ark 3-D. There is nothing preventing these games from running the way they should but Bethesda.If you buy this and don't leave an extremely negative review, you are personally contributing to these bad ports on steam. Any and all encouragement to buy this by Curators should be met with extreme distrust and assumption of shilling. You can't play this as it ships and leave with a good impression unless you are a fool completely ignorant of PC Gaming and DOOM. As someone who has spent hundreds of hours playing DOOM, as someone who considers DOOM to be in the high end of their Top 5 Games of All Time, this is not how you should experience doom. Buyer Beware.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
DOOM!As old as it may be, this game has aged quite well compared to many other FPS games. Even despite its age it still feels unique and once you get used to mouse controls, feels so very tight and responsive.It's a great game to throw yourself back into the days before cover shooting and rechargable health/shields and quicktime events and linear cooridoor level design. You'll find yourself seeking out each secret to get the most badass weapons. You could play at your own pace: carefully exploring every step of the way to survive or just simply running out guns blazing, leaving a trail of destruction in your wake.WARNING: This game will leave you wanting more in your other FPS; something more than Bay-esque scripted explosions, something more than NPCs running around you to shoot the things you're stuck on. Luckily there is DOOM II to fill that itching desire.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Doom is easily one of my favorite games and by far is one of the most fun first person shooters of all time. For those of you who do not know doom is the grandaddy of all first person shooters but the first was wolfenstein 3d. However doom was what sparked peoples interest in the genre and the concept. Since dooms release their have been mods, sequels, etc. but I do not know if anything will beat the classic doom.  The game has no multiplayer but its singleplayer is fairly simple and a load of fun. Demons from hell have taken over mars and it is up to you to prevent the demons from reaching earth. Alltogether it is very violent so not for kids, but you will have to be the one to make that call for sure. Obviously you will end up in very satanic locations so it is not for the very faint of heart. By todays standards it is not so scary of a horror game but you have to take note it was made in the 1970s. I would strongly reccomend this game to anyone who likes comics, firstperson shooters, action movies and all you halo fans! enjoy!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												A classic. While the horror has worn out nowadays, the gameplay is still very fun. It's not too hard to pick up and play, as it's basically "Shoot things and pick up keys". Don't expect a riveting plot. There are "cutscenes" at the end of the episodes but they're mainly very basic and slightly snarky.A recommendation I have is to download a source port (EG. ZDoom or Zandronum) so you can try the mods. The mods are the main things that keep me coming back. While the game itself is fair enough, the mods just add to the fun. Especially ones that replace weapons and monsters. Heck, I've made a few myself.Expect lots of pixelated and cheesy gore with satanism that looks like stuff out of a 90s rock band. While back in the day it was shocking, it's mainly kind of corny. It doesn't effect the gameplay value, however.Anyways, this is a good game and you should try it. If you like FPSes and don't just limit yourself to modern day shooters like CoD, you might like it.

Skal du prøve et FPS i verden så vælg Doom. det er noget af det sjoveste i Coop , Banerne er i verdens klasse og musikken er heller ikke dårlig med referencer til kendte metal numre. er der for alvor skabt action.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												With all of the first person classics I have played lately. Games like Team Fortress 2, Metroid other M, and the many games with first person moments in game.  You really learn to appreciate where stuff had its real start.   Sure the graphics are really dated by today's standereds. The game play is simple, and the story well, isn't really needed.  You are here, You have a pistol, You see tons of fellow characters dead on the floor, and everything is trying to kill you.  You are awesome, so you Fight back. This game has alot of the elements used in modern games.  Mini maps, Changing weapons such as the pistol, Shotgun, and my personal fave, the Chain gun.   To a lesser extent there is the worry about ammo loss, You dont regenerate so you actually have to watch your health amount and Armor remaining.   To be honest this game is actually alot harder now that I played games like Halo and Tf2.     I honestly belive that any fan of FPS games be it Tf2, those army COD games, or just shooters in general should come and try this and maybe Quake too.   IF for nothing else than to see the place here FPS REALLY began. [I have played Wolfen stein.. and yes it was first.. but Doom is FAR better in my opinion.]

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 29, 2013
												Do you remember DOOM? The old grandpa of first person shooters? Well I don't. I wasn't born when it came out. But in the year of 2009 I found out about this miraculous game. Amazing graphics (For 1993 at least), challenging pussles, incredibly frustratingly difficult levels that keep you♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off enough so that you can't let the game win. Well, at least if you play on ''ULTRA VIOLENCE'' like I do. If you wanna have a walk in the park then the lower difficulties keep you entertained enough. The controls can feel a bit slow on the default settings but everything can be tweaked if you use the GZdoom sourceport. Doesn't matter which sourceport you use but for the love of god make sure you use one as the game is ugly and plays like♥♥♥♥♥♥in normal DOSbox mode. (It's just a program you download to up the resolution a bit, lots of other stuff and to get support for the incredibly popular mod ''Brutal DOOM''.) Even if you generally don't like fps games I truly recommend you try this piece of gaming history. Trust me, this is not anything like Call of Copy or Battlefield. So do yourself a favor and try the original game that set the world on fire. And if you don't, well, there's a dimensional shambler around that corner!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												If you plan on buying this, unless you are getting this for nostalgia's sake and want to play it in Dosbox (Steam will open Dosbox and run Doom inside it when you click play), I would suggest getting a sourceport such as Zandronum or GZDoom and playing Doom from there. The options are a lot more customizable and you can do things like enable jumping, crouching, freelook (The original Doom engine didn't allow players to look up and down), and lots more. What's even better are the mods and their ease of use with a sourceport. My favorite by far is Brutal Doom by Sgt.Mark IV which makes the game 10x more violent than the original and a lot faster paced. Blowing off limbs and heads of demons is just a small part of what this mod contains. I've probably put more than 100 hours into Brutal Doom and it never gets old. It brings Doom up to modern standards of games and yet it leaves the original charm of Doom intact. John Romero, the lead designer for Doom gave it his approval and even showed it at the 20th anniversary party of Doom that he held. So if you get this game, be sure to get Brutal Doom for it as well.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												If you can't run Ultimate Doom then look up something called "ZDoom" its a source a port that takes your game files and places them in the ZDoom folder and enables you to play in high resolutions and have no issues at all.So if you feel like smashing your computer and feel like selling them game because it won't work.Trust me search ZDoom and download it.just click on the exe and it will tell you to select your Doom game (Doom,Doom 2,Ultimate Doom etc) and it will work.It is also fully legal.The thing that shocks me today is that a 1993 old school fps game can still scare the crap out of me.It is extremely fun to blast away monsters and demons with a shotgun and then spray some undead humans with a machine gun.Thats why this game works and thats why people still love this today.Its the fact that its so simple yet so addictive and thats why it worked in 1993 because their wasn't anything as realistic or fun as Doom.It changed the way that games was aimed at mature audiences and the way it made you feel like you were in a virtual reality.The difficulty is hard if your used to the "Your Hurt,Take cover!" Call Of Duty staple.So there might be a slight difficulty spike.But if you like FPS games or like games in general and you want to try something new then buy this game and enjoy a real milestone in FPS history.10/10

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												With DOSbox (the DOS emulator that the game comes with), the game is... Okay at best. The controls are awkward as all hell because you are forced to turn your character with the arrow keys. "Why can't you aim with the mouse?" you may ask, well, you can... Except the mouse also makes your character move forward and backward by one step. Why that's even a thing, I have no idea. You shoot your weapons with Control, and let me tell you, that WILL cramp your fingers after a while. Furthermore, you can't remap the controls, which means you're stuck with a control scheme that is more awkward than Miley Cyrus trying to twerk (though that isn't DOSbox's fault, that's just how the game is). The game will also runs at no higher than 30 FPS (if that) with DOSbox, so you could have a bloody Titan X and it would still run like my old laptop (i.e. like s%#@). Overall, Doom running on DOSbox is not a very rewarding experience. A more listy version of this review:PROS:The game runsCONS:Controls cannot be remappedCapped framerateCannot aim with mouseGame runs poorly overallThough the game's performance with DOSbox may make you want to be dead, fear not, as there is something better. Zandronum is another means of running the game. And let me tell you, it's almost as good as I imagine getting to massage Gaben's soft, luscious nipples would be. Doom running on Zandronum is absolute blissful, euphoric perfection, and that's no exaggeration. Zandronum basically modernizes the features of the game, while keeping the core gameplay intact. With Zandronum, you can aim with the mouse and edit your control scheme. The framerate will not be capped either, which means the game will run at upwards of 75 FPS. It even runs like a dream on the base model of Intel HD Graphics (32 MB of dedicated RAM? Daf*q?)! What's more, you can download the Brutal Doom mod. Brutal Doom changes the weapons, new enemy death animations, and adds a gut-wrenching amount of blood and gore (it drips from the CEILING, for Gaben's sake). Zandronum also gives you the option to use either the original graphics engine or OpenGL, which will make everything look smoother, as well as add some modernized lighting effects that a PC from 1994 would have blown up trying to render. A more listified version of this review is as follows:PROS:Uncapped framerateMouse aimingCOMPLETELY customizable control schemeAbility to use the Brutal Doom modRuns beautifully, even on weak hardwareOverall experience comparable to giving Gaben a nipple massageCONS:Makes you think of Gaben, which will render you far too randy to be able to focus on the game12/10 - would rub Gaben's nips again... and again... and again... and aga........

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												This may sound strange, but I've never played the original DOOM (or really any DOOM title) until now. But I figured I wanted to play the title that cemented the FPS genre as we know it today, and also have a**loads of fun.However, I'm not one who gives titles free passes just because they're "historic" or "influential". You can tell me about how important Super Mario Bros. was for saving the video game industry from crashing in 1985, but I'll simply reply, "It's still just a platformer with no real substance. It's fun, I'll give you that, but there's not much to it." And that's the same argument I'll make with DOOM. There is no cohesive narrative. You just run from level to level, shooting demons in the face until their faces explode from the amount of lead you pump into them. Again, it's really, really fun... it just lacks enough substance to be considered substantial compared to the more narrative FPS games of today.Now, don't think for a second that I hate DOOM. Because I don't. Much like Super Mario Bros., DOOM is fast-pasted, aesthetically pleasing, and incredibly addicting and fun. I enjoyed the weekend I spent wasting my time getting to the Spider-Demon.However, there are some problems that popped up while I was played. In my very brief Half-Life review, I commented on how Gordon Freeman hovered and slid a bit. DOOM must have started that trend, because controlling Doomguy is a pain in the a**, especially when running across a ledge and being shot at, where I'd normally fall back down into the pit of lava or poison I had just come from. The level design can also be a bit cryptic. I didn't mind the first three Episodes, they were pretty straightforward. But Episode Four took all the conventions of its predecessors and threw them out the window. I like consistency in my games, is what I'm saying. I like to know that the game is following its own established rules.Other than that, there's isn't much standing in my way for recommending this game. It's an old 1990's PC FPS classic, and I certainly think anyone who loves Call of Duty, Battlefield, or Halo should go back and check out the game that started it all.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												A classic game from a simpler time before day 1 DLC, always online requirements, big budgets and forgettable storylines, DOOM still stands up as a boatload of fun.   The premise is simple.  You are a space marine trapped on an installation on the Martian moon Phobos.  Something has happened to turn all of your fellow marines into zombies, and daemons have been unleased.  Everything wants to kill you in some horrible way.  Pick up some weapons from wherever you can find them and kill everything in site before it kills you.  The gameplay still stands up after all this time, however compared to a modern game, the controls feel quite clunky.  Due to limitations in the game engine, you cannot for example, look up.  In the steam version you do get the option to re-map the forward / back / strafe left and right from the "traditional" arrow key controls to the more familiar WASD keys.  So you will use the mouse to look left and right, and fire your weapon.  The space bar is the catch all key to open doors; operate switches and levers etc...  I had DOSBox already installed on my PC for some other classic games, so I don't know if you need to have this already in order to run it, or if Steam will take care of this for you.  The game was originally coded to run on the MS-DOS operating system, and the fact that it runs at all on a modern Windows OS is pretty neat.  DOSBox is a free DOS emulator which you can install to run DOS applications (such as games) on your Windows PC.  A simple Google search can turn it up. One thing I have found is that the graphics in the game will occasionally glitch out and stop displaying properly.  Saving, quitting out and restarting seem to fix the issue.  The fact that it is running at all is a bit of a triumph, so this is really a minor issue.Perhaps the best thing about DOOM, and something that still shines through in this version is the sound and music.  The music is simple, but at the same time it's one of the best soundtracks for a game ever.  It manages to crank up the tension so well that the game is still able to make you jump out of your seat when a daemon shrieks at you from a darkened corridor and launches a fireball in your face.   The sound effects are some of the best ever put into a game.  The visceral feeling of the sound of cocking and unloading the shotgun has never been matched   in any other game since, IMHO. My only other minor complaint with this version is the apparent lack of multi-player support.  The game itself is great on its own, but most of my best memories of playing DOOM where sitting around the flat in uni with my flatmates and our PC's connected via NULL Modem links playing death matches until the wee hours of the morning.  I believe DOOM 2 had support for IPX/SPX connections.  I've not seen anything to that effect in this version, so perhaps it's no longer an option.  Which is a bit of a shame.Bottom line, should you buy this game if you've never played DOOM before?  In short, yes you should.  Just don't expect it to be anything like a modern FPS shooter.  This game was an evolution from Castle Wolfenstien, and was incredible for its day, and it's still a blast to play, however you need to expect that the graphics are going to look dated and that the controls are nowhere near as smooth and intuitive as in a modern game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Consider it a very mildly positive recommendation.The game itself sure deserves to be played as the cult classic it is, but I assume you already know what to expect already and want to know if you should buy it on Steam.Well, there are reasons for you to do it, and also reasons against.To begin with, if you absolutely want to get the original game without resorting to piracy, I'm not sure you can get a digital copy anywhere else than on Steam, so you don't really have a choice. (Otherwise, you have plenty of easy ways to get your hands on this game.)I must say, giving Steam users the opportunity to play and rediscover this great game series is commendable. It's however handled rather poorly. Basically, you will pay 10 bucks (do yourself a favor and buy the Classic Complete package if you're going to buy this game anyways) for an emulated version of the original game running through an outdated version of DOSBox, while there are a lot of source ports doing hell of a better job for free.Now, I personnally don't have any issue with this (hence, the positive recommendation), and besides a few graphical glitches when I sometimes alt+tabbed in full screen mode, the game worked perfectly fine in this state. Judging by the negative reviews, though, the version of DOSBox it's running on isn't compatible with Windows 8 and requires messing with the game files in order to even launch.Being an emulated game also means the max. available resolution is rather low, and it will upscale pretty badly if you want to go full screen on modern monitors. But you're not looking for HD graphics on this game, are you?So be warned that while I recommend it from my personal experience, said experience may vary greatly depending on your OS.If you lived in a cave the past 20+ years or are too young to remember audio tapes, VHS and floppy disks, you might need a brief introduction that will help you know what you're stepping into.DOOM is mainly known for popularizing the FPS genre, along with Wolfenstein 3D, and, later on, Quake - to a point that the FPS genre was more often called DOOM-like and Quake-like than First Person Shooter. If you're an FPS lover who enjoys mindless fun and excessive brutality, games like Unreal, Duke Nukem 3D, or modern games like Bulletstorm and the new Shadow Warrior, you have to add DOOM and DOOM II to your list of played games.Now, if you're coming from a modern FPS background, you're in for quite a shock gameplay-wise. No mouse look (not even looking up or down, which can be tricky when shooting enemies up on platforms or down a set of stairs), no crosshair to target enemies, no reloading, and very basic movements. You can only go forward/backward, turn left/right, and run - forget about crouching, jumping, walking slowly, or even strafing. Well, there is strafing, but it will require you to use turn left/right keys while holding another key, which is quite counter-intuitive when you're not used to it. This game actually plays a lot better with a gamepad provided you have the third-party tool to activate gamepad support.If you still want to enjoy this game without going through the chore of adapting to the peculiar control scheme of the time, I recommend using Chocolate DOOM to play this game (check out the Steam forum to see how to install it). This source port is as close as it can get to the original experience, while keeping the comfort of some modern features like strafing and mouse look (you will only able to look left or right, but that's already something), and also fixing some lighting issues the Steam version got (some areas that are supposed to be pitch black are only a lot darker in this version).tl;drI recommend the game itself, but as it goes for the Steam version, make sure it works on your OS by checking out the negative reviews before buying, and take the Classic Complete package because the asking price for the game alone is too high for what it is (the original game running on an outdated DOS emulator).DOOM is a great game if you like mindless shooting, and going for 100% (all secrets/items/kills) and speed runs on each level is very fun for those who are looking for an extra challenge after completing the game once.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Doom/Doom II is one of my favorite games of all time.  It combines horror, shoot-em-up, sci-fi and occult themes into what was one of the most violent games created.  More importantly, it's fun.  Without any "realistic" features seen today (run stamina, weapon reloading, auto-life regen, jumping), Doom provides the high-octane thrill of running through tech facilities blowing up any demon you come across.  But that's not to say the game is all about rampant killing.  Most of the levels are built to be a subtle puzzle, having you search for keys and switches to find a path to the exit door.  Additionally, each level has at least one secret room/closet/pathway that leads to bonus gear to greatly help you on your way.  And despite the pixilated look (by today's standards) of the game, I firmly believe that Doom's graphics stand up very well today and provide just the right level of nostalgia for a game made in 1994.  Highly recommended.  Even if you don't beat it, at least give the first few levels a try.  They're still free via shareware.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Doom was another first person shooter that played an important role in the gaming community. Released just a year after Wolfenstein 3D, this game has similar traits except with a sense of movement on the camera, more 3-D depth on the levels, and added shadows. The plot is about a last surviving space marine who must escape from a marine base on the planet Mars that is being over run by demons and mutated marines. There are various weapons and items to collect in order to aid you on your survival. There's even an option to heighten the difficulty of the game for those who want more of a challenge. Two years after this game was released in 1993, an estimated 20 million copies have been sold, and various "Doom" clones and that is when the first person shooter genre officially became a thing in the gaming industry. Doom would become a very well known title that even non-gamers would immidiately know what it is without playing it. The success lead to a few sequals and updated versions of the game such as the "Ultimate" edition which is basically the same game only with an additional episode to it. So if you liked the Wolfenstein game, this is a must play game.

												What can I say about this game that hasn't been said a billion times over? The granddaddy of all first person shooters. The orignal, the classic, and arguably the best. This game remains the epitome of what FPS games should be. A benchmark for all companys seeking to create a fully featured shooter. Doom has a wide range of weapons, excellent combat, it's challenging, and immensly fun. Even to modern standards, it kicks♥♥♥♥♥ In it's time, there was nothing like it. Guns guns guns and monsters. Blood, guts, glory, and the salvation of the human race. It goes without saying, if you love FPS games and haven't played Doom even once, you aren't doing it right. This game is a MUST for all FPS lovers. Learn some history about your favorite genre while you blast away at demons with your trusty shotgun. Experience the game that created and shaped a whole new niche of gaming. I can go on forever about this game. It truly is, and will forever be, an incredible game.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												Doom is easily one of my favorite games and by far is one of the most fun first person shooters of all time. For those of you who do not know doom is the grandaddy of all first person shooters but the first was wolfenstein 3d. However doom was what sparked peoples interest in the genre and the concept. Since dooms release their have been mods, sequels, etc. but I do not know if anything will beat the classic doom.  The game has no multiplayer but its singleplayer is fairly simple and a load of fun. Demons from hell have taken over mars and it is up to you to prevent the demons from reaching earth. Alltogether it is very violent so not for kids, but you will have to be the one to make that call for sure. Obviously you will end up in very satanic locations so it is not for the very faint of heart. By todays standards it is not so scary of a horror game but you have to take note it was made in the 1970s. I would strongly reccomend this game to anyone who likes comics, firstperson shooters, action movies and all you halo fans! enjoy!

												its an amazing classic game. but if you want to open the game on windows 8 and make it work do the following:Run it in compatibility mode for Windows 95Then you have to edit both the Ultimate.conf and Ultimatem.conf files to change this:fullscreen=falseThen look down a little further and change this:waitonerror=falseBOTH files have these settings and BOTH files must be changed AND be the same.If those dont work do this too:fulldouble=falsein both ultimate.conf and ultimatem.conf.Now when the game starts, to use fullscreen just hit Alt+Enter.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												This is the first game in the DOOM series. The reason it is called "the ultimate doom" is because alle the episodes are included. Doom consists of four episodes, three episodes that makes up the main storyline, pluss an extra fourth episode.The Doom series is a must have for a PC-gamer born in or before the 90's. This is buy far one of the best first person shooters out there, and is therfore highly recomended. For me, and probably for a lot of other people, this game is packed with action and nostalgia.If you are running windows 7/8 you will need to run this game in compability mode for windows "XP (service pack 3)". To do this, go to: Steam>SteamApps>common>Ultimate Doom>base. In this folder you should see the dosbox.exe. Rightclikk it and go to properties. Clikk compability in the top tab. Check "Run this program in compability mode for" And choose: Windows XP (service pack 3) in the dropdown menu.For further inprovement you can change the configurationfiles for Dosbox and Doom. The configurationfiels are called: dosbox.conf, ultimate.conf and ultimatem.conf. Open the files with notepad to make your changes. If you are changing annything in this files make sure you set the same values in all three files. If you screew up with theese files, just uninstall and reinstall the game and they should be back to their default setting. In the dosbox.conf file all the different values are explained.

												Simply brilliant, yet largely overlooked these days by modern FPSes. While not a perfect game in terms of controls, this was one of the pioneer FPSes and remains a classic of the genre. I absolutely love it. The music is amazing and really has that 90s-nostalgia feel to it. The monsters are neat and unique, and the feeling you get after killing them is a wonderful feeling. The weapon arsenal is highly varied as well, with weapons of increasing power becoming obtainable later on in the game.I highly recommend it for anyone out there that plays modern FPSes and is interested in an older gaming experience, or simply someone who wants to find out what FPSes were like when they were first starting out.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												I won't lie. I was skeptical about Doom. I thought it was a piece of nostalgia that was rated to highly because it was old. But I can say confidently that this game is FUN AS HELL (pardon the pun). How do you describe Doom? Well, I can try. You shoot things. And by god is it fun. Like, (un)holy♥♥♥♥♥♥it's fun. You run through different levels shooting baddies that are either people or demons from hell! You may be thinking that this game is just pixelated COD or something. Well it isn't. I cannot express the grin on my face when I picked up the gatling gun or the rocket launcher. The adrenaline that went through me when I mowed down demons while keeping a close eye on my health. But most people have heard about how great Doom was. You want to know if it holds up. And it does. Each level is expertly designed to make you think about which  way to go. The combat is fast paced and satisfying. The gore is charming in that old fashioned way. The difficulty is nothing to laugh at to. Do you want to feel genuinely terrified that each step may lead into the jaws of an angry demon? Do you want to curse at every missed shot and scour for ammo hoping to find enough bullets to fight off the demons chasing you? Remember, this was in the 90s. Back then, their easy was our hardcore. Everything was difficult as hell (there it is again). And Nightmare on Doom was grueling even by their standards. Every moment while in combat is pure and utter fun. Every baddie slain is like a scene form Fury Road. Now does it have it's flaws? Of course. Plenty. The movement feels very strange at times, some of the controls are questionable and it can't tab out. But these are all flaws inherent with age. This was back when computers ran on DOS. It's going to have a few difficulties when running on a platform that was the ♥♥♥♥ing future when it was released. Windows 10 belonged only in Back To The Future. But strangely enough, it runs beautifully performance wise. Better than most games infact. It's only 5$ too. There is very little reason not to buy this if you are not a fan of gaming. It's a staple. It's up there with Wolfenstein, Mario and Tetris. It's a classic. It's DOOM.

Posted: May 22, 2016
												What can I possibly say about the original classic that hasn't already been said countless times before? It possesses a timeless @$$kickery that no matter how many times I return to it over the years it never seems to lose it's flavor. Much like Duke Nukem 3D I've played it on more consoles and handhelds than I can even recall anymore, both in homebrew and official ports. There's enough source ports of the PC version alone these days to make your head spin and more customizable options than you can shake a boomstick at (oh, did I mention controller support, multiplayer, etc. too?)So grab one of the source ports (or play vanilla with the supplied dosbox if you prefer and can work out the kinks with a modern PC...hit the guides and forums if you have any troubles or need help with ports/mods), I've been using ZDoom personally (which also has some variations depending on your needs), and get your fill of ULTRA VIOLENCE. :D
