number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												I'd like to think most gamers at least know what Doom is all about and why people like it, but I'll go ahead and lay it out.This is my favorite shooter game in the world, and one of my favorite games period. It nails the logical progression of difficulty in terms of enemy placement and quantity as well as map layout. This game is so replayable -- it's actually among the first few games people had the idea of speedrunning. If you're not out for speed, then you can kick the difficulty up a notch or try and get every secret. Every weapon has a distinct application (save for the handgun) and feels satisfying to use. Fantastic gunplay.The Doom engine itself is divine, one of the best I can think of. The game is as challenging as you want it to be, anywhere from♥♥♥♥♥♥easy (I'm too young to die!) to brutally hard (Nightmare)You can't ignore the music and graphics either. Some of the best, most appropriate game music and graphics that have aged incredibly well. The atmosphere in Doom is absolutely flawless. Never does the game fail to make me feel like I've got a monstrous task ahead of me. Sometimes you'll be anxious to activate a switch that is so obviously a trap and you don't know if you can make it out alive, but you have to activate it anyway if you want to progess. At others, you'll channel the badass nature of your space marine avatar and let nobody out of your clutches. You're supposed to feel like this is a hell (heh) of a task to take on, but also that you're exactly the man for the job, and that's exactly the feeling Doom gives me.With only select Bethesda ARPGs coming even close, Doom is probably the most modded game in the world. There are countless megaWADs, level packs, and gameplay-altering mods. And you can bet your sweet♥♥♥♥♥there's multiplayer mods available, each with level packs and gameplay mods of their own. Mods are coming out faster than you can probably play them, so don't worry about running out of content. With the base game and all these mods that have been coming out since the early '90s, anyone who gets a kick out of this game can easily get hundreds of hours of enjoyment out of it.Basically, Doom is one of the most polished, most well-designed games on Earth (and Mars, and Hell) and I could play it forever.10/10

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												With all of the first person classics I have played lately. Games like Team Fortress 2, Metroid other M, and the many games with first person moments in game.  You really learn to appreciate where stuff had its real start.   Sure the graphics are really dated by today's standereds. The game play is simple, and the story well, isn't really needed.  You are here, You have a pistol, You see tons of fellow characters dead on the floor, and everything is trying to kill you.  You are awesome, so you Fight back. This game has alot of the elements used in modern games.  Mini maps, Changing weapons such as the pistol, Shotgun, and my personal fave, the Chain gun.   To a lesser extent there is the worry about ammo loss, You dont regenerate so you actually have to watch your health amount and Armor remaining.   To be honest this game is actually alot harder now that I played games like Halo and Tf2.     I honestly belive that any fan of FPS games be it Tf2, those army COD games, or just shooters in general should come and try this and maybe Quake too.   IF for nothing else than to see the place here FPS REALLY began. [I have played Wolfen stein.. and yes it was first.. but Doom is FAR better in my opinion.]

content:
Posted: May 29, 2013
												Do you remember DOOM? The old grandpa of first person shooters? Well I don't. I wasn't born when it came out. But in the year of 2009 I found out about this miraculous game. Amazing graphics (For 1993 at least), challenging pussles, incredibly frustratingly difficult levels that keep you♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off enough so that you can't let the game win. Well, at least if you play on ''ULTRA VIOLENCE'' like I do. If you wanna have a walk in the park then the lower difficulties keep you entertained enough. The controls can feel a bit slow on the default settings but everything can be tweaked if you use the GZdoom sourceport. Doesn't matter which sourceport you use but for the love of god make sure you use one as the game is ugly and plays like♥♥♥♥♥♥in normal DOSbox mode. (It's just a program you download to up the resolution a bit, lots of other stuff and to get support for the incredibly popular mod ''Brutal DOOM''.) Even if you generally don't like fps games I truly recommend you try this piece of gaming history. Trust me, this is not anything like Call of Copy or Battlefield. So do yourself a favor and try the original game that set the world on fire. And if you don't, well, there's a dimensional shambler around that corner!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												DOOM is a classic for a reason, and it's still a blast to play. The combat is fast-paced, visceral, and immensely satisfying. The levels are well-designed, and they are complex without being maze-like. There are a variety of enemies with different attacks and movement styles, and they range in toughness from annoying cannon-fodder zombies all the way to the giant, rocket-shooting, insanely deadly Cyberdemon. On top of all that, the sound effects, gore, and hellish imagery serve to create a sense of atmosphere that nicely rounds out the gameplay experience.The controls, and the inability to look up or down, give DOOM a slight learning curve for first-time players. However, with just a little practice you'll be fine. Additionally, mods like Brutal Doom bring a lot of cool new things to the DOOM experience, including modern FPS controls.Simply put, DOOM is a must-have game for anyone who's a fan of FPS games.

												Doom was one of the very first FPS and helped massivley progress the genre into one of the biggest video game genres out there. I had heard all this and much more about how amazong this game was yet I was hugley sceptical of the as I belived it must be alot of nostaliga that is affecting people view on the game. So I bought the game to try it out myself, at first I wasn't keen on it atall as im used to modern titles such as COD and battlefield. But onec I got into the game I realized I was have so much more fun than I did on say a call of duty campaign. The graphics are bad and you cant look up or down but it didn't affect me atall as the game is just so much fun. In reflection this game is one of my all time favourite FPS games and maybe even one of my top 10 games of all time, ok maybe im pushing it with top 10 games of all time as there are so many good games out there. I think I got my point accross though that this game is indeed an amazing game and not just a nostaliga throw back.The weapons are immesnsily satisiying especially the shot gun and the soundtrack is also fantastic, the levels are also laid out greatly. I would give this game a full 10/10 and think that this really is the "classic" that many deem it. I would recommend this to anyone.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Often referred to as the 'Father of FPS' (Wolfenstein 3D being the grandfather), DOOM by iD software is an absolute tour de force. 21 years later and it still holds its place as one of the greatest shooters of all time. The weapons feel good, sound and level design are top notch, and the nostalgia feels are off the chart. DOSbox has now been incorporated into this release, making it possible to run hassle free on basically any system. Pick this up and battle your way through the shores of hell.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Doom is proof that while technological supremacy is fleeting, good game design is forever. Twenty-plus years after its release, it still stands tall as one of the greatest first person shooters ever made, an orgy of twitchy bloody death and destruction matched only by its own sequel. All the game needs to make you forget it came out in the early 90's is a fresh coat of paint, and all it takes is a few free downloads to cover that. GZDoom ports the game engine to run natively on windows, instead of requiring DOSbox, and gives the game a host of modern conveniences features like fully 3D environment rendering, texture filtering, and most importantly, proper mouse look. Brutal Doom, probably one of the best and most comprehensive mods ever made, fills out the package by overhauling the soundtrack, adding buckets and buckets of gore, and rebalancing the gameplay to be faster and more intense than ever.If you're willing to take a few minutes to set it up properly, Doom is absolutely worth your time. It was great then, and thanks to twenty years of technical advancements and a somewhat overzealous fan community, it's even better now.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 10, 2013
												It's amusing why I'm writting this, since it's DOOM for ♥♥♥♥ sake, but I'll get to it. Anyway for those that have experienced this game all those years ago and haven't touched it since, I advise to pick it up, play, to relieve the nostalgia, then hop onto the mod scene for a kick in the nuts surprise. Anyway, it is one of the first FPS games that started the genre and got me interested in it. (Though to be fair Duke Nukem 3D was the real spark for me for shooters, and Quake was what got me into competitive MP portion of the genre).The vanilla experience is extremely dated, no proper aiming, clunky controls by today's standard, heavy reliance on auto aim and naturaly the primitive graphics. Even with all that I played the vanilla recently (though I ended up modding it via zdoom for better control scheme) and still was fun as ever. Secrets were ♥♥♥♥ well hidden (for those that I couldn't remember), shooting still felt great. Amusing how a primitive shooter like Doom can have such great shooting feeling. Enemies will flinch depending on guns, rockets will gib and blast stuff apart and BFG will clear rooms. The level design was fantastic, mazelike key hunting formula that made a lot of old games great, and put a large majority of modern games to shame when it comes to inteligent level design. While I had an absolute blast with Doom, and not just due to nostalgia, I encountered the large amount of fantastic mods. At first I take this with a grain of salt. Mods for games are peculiar, usually extremely specific, niche or such. Here or there there will be some that truly stand out. In Doom's case, good God are there a lot of great mods. I'm not going to rattle them off but I will mention one particular mod that enhances the experience to modern standars, and puts to shame almost every known FPS developer today. I'm talking about Brutal Doom mod. If you liked doom, any iteration of it, go look this up. It takes the entire old game/s and tuns it to 11 with gore, weapons, effects, sound and feeling. To me this mod made Doom game so much more in standard with current games. Doom already was a pinacle, had nothing to prove since it stood among the first and best, but with mods like this it really makes me ask: what the ♥♥♥♥ are current FPS devs doing. The original game is timleess, and while I admit there is some nostalgia there, there are still a lot of technical aspects (gameplay wise) that hold strong even 20 years after. With mods (like Brutal Doom), all bets are off, this is balls to the walls amazing value in a game that offers everything a shooter should have. Shooting is fun, satisfying, strategic, skill based, and no matter how much they throw at you you will want more to paint the walls with (that is quite literal in Brutal Doom's case).If you feel that game requires fancy graphics to be good, you are in the wrong game genre. This game right here does everything justice in terms of shooting, level exploration, wit, and just not giving a ♥♥♥♥. Go to hell, and make them sorry they ever heard of you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												So this is it- the infamous DOOM I've heard so much about. Don't be fooled by my six minute playtime- I've spent much, much longer running this masterpiece through ZDoom.This game may be older than I am, but holy hell (see what I did there?) it wipes the floor with modern FPS games.Graphics:Again, this game is older than I am.  You could run this thing on a printer.  However, that is no reason not to play this game.Gameplay:This game and Wolfenstein pioneered the FPS genre. Pick up guns, point, and blast demons back to the holes from whence they came. No crappy ADS system to assist you. Navigate through the level, find the key cards, and move on to the next level. Move around walls and press the activate button- you may just reveal a secret room filled with a treasure trove of power ups and weapons.Story:Eeeeeeeh. The game doesn't do too good a job of storytelling. It tells you that demons have emerged on Mars, and YOU (Doomguy) are the only survivor! From there on out, you singlehandedly rip their pixelated hides to bloody bits.Soundtrack:Do you like heavy metal? I sure as hell do. Your ears are treated to 8-bit repetitions of guitar riffs from the likes of Metallica and Pantera. Can't complain.Overall:If you haven't played this game, play it. Killing demons old-school is the only way to kill demons. This game gets a 9/10 from me.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												I was wrong about this game. I had trouble enjoying it, until I started playing it on easy mode through a third-party Doom engine like Doomsday or ZDoom. Doomsday has an option to disable the motion-sickness-inducing view bobbing, and has a map overlay that makes navigating the byzantine levels more fun for a modern gamer. Easy mode is built in to the regular game (there are 5 difficulty settings, and the default is the one in the middle), and I found it much more fun to treat the game like a shooting gallery in a maze (with a map that fills out as you go through the level) than a tough as nails, player versus the world hellscape.There are people who played Doom when it came out and still love the original game for what it is. The majority of current FPS gamers have never played it, but they should. Maybe they can't appreciate it in the same way as the original fans, but if they're like me they can still enjoy the incredible shooting mechanics. Among all first-person shooters, this game has one of the best and most satisfying to use shotguns, for example.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												One of the best FPS games of all time. It was so ahead of its time when it came out, that despite missing a lot of features found in modern FPS titles, Doom manages to make you forget all of those things and just shoot everything. If I were to complain about anything, it would be that Dosbox can be a little clunky at times. And the graphics are really good, they're just a bit blurry. Playing through ZDoom and getting rid of the jump button and crouch button, lets you enjoy the masterpiece in it's original glory without any blur. The game itself is also not very long for a first playthrough. I played on Ultra-Violence and it only took me about 10 hours. But the amount of time you're going to be spending replaying the game, trying to find every secret and the countless mods there are to play (both new single player maps and original game enhancements like Brutal Doom) will leave you with countless hours of entertainment.For anyone who hasn't played Doom and is worried about the graphics, just look up Doom Source Ports on Google, look up how to setup Steam to launch a source port through the library and good times are to be had with this masterpiece.

												What can I say about this game that hasn't been said a billion times over? The granddaddy of all first person shooters. The orignal, the classic, and arguably the best. This game remains the epitome of what FPS games should be. A benchmark for all companys seeking to create a fully featured shooter. Doom has a wide range of weapons, excellent combat, it's challenging, and immensly fun. Even to modern standards, it kicks♥♥♥♥♥ In it's time, there was nothing like it. Guns guns guns and monsters. Blood, guts, glory, and the salvation of the human race. It goes without saying, if you love FPS games and haven't played Doom even once, you aren't doing it right. This game is a MUST for all FPS lovers. Learn some history about your favorite genre while you blast away at demons with your trusty shotgun. Experience the game that created and shaped a whole new niche of gaming. I can go on forever about this game. It truly is, and will forever be, an incredible game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												I'm not sure if it's just for Windows 8 users, but I definitely had some trouble running this game as-is. I did finally manage to get it working (by hitting the home key right as DOSBox began and then going back into the game), but I ran into lag and sound issues.If anyone is experiencing any sort of problems with any Doom I or II games on Steam, the best way to fix it is to download ZDOOM (a newer engine that runs Doom just like it was played originally, but with higher resolution and more options) and copy all the files into the directory where "dosbox.exe" is. To get to the game's folder easier, you can just right click it from the Steam games list, click properties, and then find "Browse local files...". Delete the original dosbox.exe file, and then rename zdoom.exe to dosbox.exe, so Steam will recognize it and automatically run it for you every time. This will make sure it runs your Doom .wads on every computer without trouble. If this helped you, please give this review a thumbs up to help spread the word. Thanks! :) Anyways, that aside, onto the review:I'll make it short and sweet. Doom is one of the best first person shooter video games to this day. Wayyyy way back in the early 90s, id Software revolutionized the FPS genre with Wolfenstein 3D, and then ultimately cemented it into gaming as we know it with the release of the first Doom. It plays very well, even to this day (although you may have to adjust some controls for maximum precision and more comfort). You'll have fun running through each level, blasting zombies and imps to pieces with anything from a pistol to a shotgun, all the way to a chaingun or a BFG. Don't look the acronym up, kids. And those aren't all the weapons the game has, either. I won't spoil it for you, though. There are loads of enemies to do battle with, and all the levels are extremely complex. There will be doors opening behind you, keycards that you need to find in order to get to the next room, secret hidden hallways, etc. The music is perfect in all its MIDI glory. The modding community has always been faithful. Check out Brutal Doom if you want to know what I'm talking about. I mainly bought the entire Classic Complete pack just to have the WADs legally. That's right, lawyers and PC haters. Not all of us just sit around pirating games all day. If we really love it, we'll buy it. Anyways, with these WADs, you can copy them directly from your Steam folder and use them on other source ports for features such as playing multiplayer on modern servers, upgrading the graphics/resolution, and, of course, modding. There are also methods of creating your very own WADs, which is one thing that's made Doom such a popular game. It has stood the test of time for 2 decades, and I see it going for even more than that. It's a classic. Just like Super Mario Bros., Sonic The Hedgehog, and The Legend of Zelda. Definitely pick this one up. I have no complaints for this version of the game, other than what I said about it possibly not working for everyone's machines when first downloaded. But follow my guide up there, and you'll have it fixed in minutes. It's really easy, even for those not tech savvy. 10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 17, 2013
												DOOM is a great game, and it's an awesome experience for any FPS player. It's not one of those games that has you going straight from point A to point B. You have to explore the maps to find keys that you to proceed to the next map. There is a wide mariety of maps, this version of DOOM has a total of 36 maps if you also count the secret maps. Some maps can be a maze, however, and it can ruin the pace of the game. The game also has a lot of secrets and even a few secret levels. DOOM also has a good variety of enemies, some can be annoying though, such as the Lost Souls, the pinky Demons with partial invisibility, and the Cacodemons. The bosses are probably the most badass bosses in gaming, a giant robot demon with a rocket launcher for a hand, and a robot spider demon with a chaingun. I won't count the bruiser brothers, because they're just two Barons of Hell. The game also offers some kick♥♥♥♥♥music, which adds good pace to the game, although some songs can be a bit boring, but most of them are awesome. It has some really neat powerups such as +100% health, invinsibility, increased damage, +200% armor, partial invisibility, a sphere that brings your health and armor to the max (200%), and a radiation suit. You start with 2 weapons, your fists, and a pistol. The other weapons, which you earn as you progress through the game are a shotgun, a chaingun, a rocket launcher, a plasma gun, and the almighty BFG 9000, this weapon is a beast and can kill multiple enemies with one hit, and it's also an easy way to quickly end a boss fight, but it is very overpowered, and might ruin the fun unless you're a psychopath, which you probably are if you can't stay away from DOOM. The gameplay is quite simple, find what you need to continue to the next map and shoot whatever is alive. No living thing here is your friend. The controls can be awkward for players, you use the up and down arrow keys to move forwards and backwards, and the left and right arrow keys to turn left and right, left control shoots, alt strafes, shift sprints, and space flicks switches and pushes buttons, they aren't rebindable. But you can still use GZDoom, which has rebindable keys mouse looking, and it allows you to move left and right. And GZDoom also quickly starts the game, which is something we should really thank the dudes who made GZDoom for because the game takes about a minute to finally get to the main menu.TL;DR: Doom is awesome, some things can be a bit meh, GZDoom can fix some flaws. My individual rating the aspects I talked about are:Gameplay: 10/10Enemies: 8/10Map design: 8/10Music: 9/10Weapons: 8/10Controls: 6/10 (GZDoom fixes that)Time to load the game: 0/10 (GZDoom makes is a 10/10)Simplicity: 10/10Bosses: 8/10Powerups: 10/10Maps: 7/10Overall score: 7.6/10

												Doom is easily one of my favorite games and by far is one of the most fun first person shooters of all time. content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
DOOM!As old as it may be, this game has aged quite well compared to many other FPS games. Even despite its age it still feels unique and once you get used to mouse controls, feels so very tight and responsive.It's a great game to throw yourself back into the days before cover shooting and rechargable health/shields and quicktime events and linear cooridoor level design. You'll find yourself seeking out each secret to get the most badass weapons. You could play at your own pace: carefully exploring every step of the way to survive or just simply running out guns blazing, leaving a trail of destruction in your wake.WARNING: This game will leave you wanting more in your other FPS; something more than Bay-esque scripted explosions, something more than NPCs running around you to shoot the things you're stuck on. Luckily there is DOOM II to fill that itching desire.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												I was wrong about this game. I had trouble enjoying it, until I started playing it on easy mode through a third-party Doom engine like Doomsday or ZDoom. Doomsday has an option to disable the motion-sickness-inducing view bobbing, and has a map overlay that makes navigating the byzantine levels more fun for a modern gamer. Easy mode is built in to the regular game (there are 5 difficulty settings, and the default is the one in the middle), and I found it much more fun to treat the game like a shooting gallery in a maze (with a map that fills out as you go through the level) than a tough as nails, player versus the world hellscape.There are people who played Doom when it came out and still love the original game for what it is. The majority of current FPS gamers have never played it, but they should. Maybe they can't appreciate it in the same way as the original fans, but if they're like me they can still enjoy the incredible shooting mechanics. Among all first-person shooters, this game has one of the best and most satisfying to use shotguns, for example.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												I was 4 years old when Doom came out. Wow. Has it been that long? 4 years old, and I would never had thought games could be any better than Doom. It still almost seems that way. It was Wolfenstein 3D, and Doom, that got me hooked on FPS games. Later when the other FPS games that followed after Doom came out like, Quake, Decent 1 & 2, all would solidify my cravings to be the one to pull the trigger. Doom is a household name! The somewhat endless stories of people suffering from sleep depervation because Doom was so addictive is just awesome to hear, because I know personally what they mean. I remember I would sometimes through a fit, because my parents would make me go to bed. But, I know if my parents would've let me played as long as I desired, then I would definitely have stayed up for days playing Doom. That's not good for the health. Nope, nope. Hey, one time my friends and I stood up for three days straight just to beat Duke Nukem 3D. Lol, good times. Awe, man! When, I turn 40 years old, I will expect you future kids to know Doom. You kids now have the privilege to either choose to play this old Doom game, or some new, hyped up, Next-Gen, game coming out next week. When I was you're age, Doom was the Next-Gen game for us, and boy does it still rock! Not to make you kids feel underprivileged because you were born late, no, I'm just suggesting you to buy Doom, and see why it became a huge turning point in the history of gaming. You're gonna wish that you love it as much as we who grew up with it do, and that's an encouraging thought. There are so many great FPS games out there, but Doom will always have its rightful spot in my collection.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												DOOM 1 is perhaps the ultimate classic game that everyone even remotely interested in first-person shooters should at least try out once. And I say this, admittedly, as someone who simply cannot enjoy games with outdated graphics. That is unless the game is really special to me, having played it lots in the past. And I admit, too, that I only rather recently bought Ultimate and Final Doom, quite a bit after I played the newest DOOM (2016) for almost 60 hours.So no, the oldschool Doom games weren't about some retro trip. They're all about pure fun. And let me tell you, it's so, so much fun, no matter if you play with classic controls (using only the arrow keys, ctrl and spacebar), WASD keys with horizontal mouse aim (as is standard in this version, though I advise you to look up how to lock your y-axis), or simply replace the exe with a Doom interpreter to run amazing mods such as Brutal DOOM, where you have fully fleshed out "modern" controls, lots of gore and just an overall amazing experience. And you can customize it however you want, utilizing the tons of maps & mods that have been developed over the last two decades.So, overall, I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												If you have a Steam account and have not played Doom, you're committing a crime against humanity. You are obviously a demon, and need to go back to hell. Or, you could play Doom and redeem yourself by cutting your way through hordes of your brethren in a fast-paced, brutal shooter that pioneered the shooter genre. Then, once you're done, download some .wad files off the internet and do it again. There's 22+ years of content out there, and dedicated modders are still pumping it out. Plus, if the original 320x240 resolution and keyboard only controls aren't cutting it for you, you can download source ports that fit every need. Hell, if you really wanted to, you can take the .wad file that comes with the game, find an appropriate source port, and play Doom on basically anything. I've seen it played on printers, ATMs, and I'm pretty sure as soon as a toaster comes out with a screen, Doom won't be too far away. So, what's your excuse, then? Are ya chicken?
